review.title: Mining relevant interval rules
review.abstract: This article extends the method of Garriga et al. for mining relevant rules to numerical attributes by extracting interval-based pattern rules. We propose an algorithm that extracts such rules from numerical datasets using the interval-pattern approach from Kaytoue et al. This algorithm has been implemented and evaluated on real datasets.
histories: International Conference on Formal Concept Analysis, Jun 2017, Rennes, France. Supplementary proceedings of International Conference on Formal Concept Analysis (ICFCA)
review.COMMENTS: International Conference on Formal Concept Analysis, Jun 2017, Rennes, France. Supplementary proceedings of International Conference on Formal Concept Analysis (ICFCA)

metadata.title: Mining relevant interval rules

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 9.03 267v 1 [cs.A I] 1 1Se p20 17Keywords: control learning, interval patterns, relevant rules, closed patterns

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Garriga et al. [2] proposed a method for extracting relevant association rules from marked items. We extend the work of Garriga et al. [3] to numerical attributes by applying the pattern mining approach of Kaytoue et al. [3], which is based on FCA (Formal Concept Analysis). Kaytoue et al. [3] proposed extending the degradation of frequently closed interval patterns to numerical data. Our work closes the gap between these two approaches to extract relevant interval pattern rules.

sections.heading: 2 Closed interval patterns
sections.text: Let F = {f1,., fn} be a fixed set of n features. We present a training example as a tuple of real values x = {x1,..., xn} where xi-p pattern (fi), with an associated class pattern. The tuple stores one value per characteristic of F. We consider two-class learning problems where the set of examples E is divided into positives (P) and negatives (N) so that E = P-P-N and P-N = common patterns can be transformed into two-class learning problems.An n-dimensional interval pattern is a tuple of intervals < [li, ui] > i-p- and negatives (N) where li, ui-P-X-X = frequency of learning problems can be transformed.

sections.heading: 3 Mining relevant interval-rules
sections.text: "The green for the green for the green" The green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green for the green "green for the green for the green" for the green for the green for the green

sections.heading: 4 Implementation and results
sections.text: We have evaluated our algorithm using three UCI datasets (Haberman, Iris and Spine) [1]. The algorithm is implemented in C + +. The experiments are carried out on an Intel Core I5 with 8Go RAM running Linux system.For all experiments in this section, fpmax = 10% and eqmod = 10. Figure 1 illustrates the number of closed interval patterns in positive examples, the number of frequent and accurate rules and the number of relevant interval pattern rules. We see that the computing times (see Figure 2) correlate strongly with the number of patterns. Even with small data such as the Iris dataset, the number of patterns for low thresholds is high (about 3000), but the number of relevant patterns is significantly lower than the total number of closed rules. In addition, the number of patterns increases exponentially with the number of modalities.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: We have introduced a new algorithm for extracting relevant rules from a numerical dataset that offers a wider choice of potentially interesting rules for experts. The number of extracted patterns is high but more representative of the input dataset, whereas standard algorithms such as CN2 or Ripper a priori select a very limited set of rules based solely on coverage and accuracy criteria. Future work will focus on proposing additional selection criteria that allow the expert to express his preferred relevant rules.
